elements.content: A new manganese–vanadate hybrid structure, Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I; bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine), has been synthesized via hydrothermal methods and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction [P21/n, Z = 4, a = 6.8557(4) Å, b = 10.4900(6) Å, c = 19.7921(13) Å, β = 96.419(4)°], infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, magnetic susceptibility measurements, and UV–vis diffuse reflectance. The structure is comprised of manganese vanadate layers with 2,2’-bipyridine ligands coordinated to the Mn(II) cations. The water molecules coordinated to the manganese sites can be reversibly desorbed at ∼190 °C with the formation of a new hybrid structure before then further decomposing to MnV2O6 upon heating to 300 °C. Notably, I undergoes a reversible structural transformation to Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II) under hydrothermal conditions. This structural transformation results from additional bpy-ligand coordination to 1/4 of the vanadium sites. Magnetic data indicate Mn(II) cations in both I and II are high spin (S = 5/2). The optical bandgap sizes of I and II were measured to be ∼2.2 eV and ∼1.6 eV, respectively, and that are calculated by DFT methods to arise primarily from Mn-to-bpy and Mn-to-V electronic transitions between the valence and conduction bands. Visible-light irradiation of II in aqueous solutions leads to photocatalytic activities for total water splitting at rates of ∼92 μmol H2/1/2O2 g–1 h–1 and ∼21 μmol H2/1/2O2 g–1 h–1 for II, with and without a 1 wt % Pt surface cocatalyst, respectively, but no measurable activity for I. Rates for only H2 production using aqueous methanol solutions were significantly lower. Results from electronic structure calculations show that the change in ligand coordination from I to II causes the excited electrons to populate slightly lower-energy bpy ligand π* orbitals that are coordinated to V(V), and thus this structural change in II leads to a better excited-state charge separation within its hybrid structure.

elements.content: The coordination of an additional bipyridine ligand results in a structural conversion from Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (left) to Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (right) and an enhanced separation of the electron density in the Mn-based valence band (blue) and ligand-based conduction-band states (purple). This structural conversion is necessary to achieve photon-driven activity for hydrogen production as well as for water splitting photocatalytic reactions.

This structural conversion is necessary to achieve photon-driven activity for hydrogen production as well as for water splitting photocatalytic reactions.

elements.content: Investigations into the use of visible-light energies to drive photocatalytic water-splitting reactions at the surfaces of metal-oxide semiconductors have drawn intense research interest in recent years, especially as a renewable route to produce hydrogen and oxygen using sunlight. Current approaches have focused on lowering the band gaps of metal oxides to absorb a greater fraction of sunlight while also maintaining a conduction band edge above the H2/H2O redox couple. Vanadium-containing oxides, such as V6O13, InVO4, BiVO4, and Ag3VO4, have been found with visible-light photocatalytic activities for O2 and H2 production. The 3d orbitals of vanadium act to lower the conduction band energies compared to the analogous titanate, niobate, and tantalate photocatalysts. Further, recent results indicate that by incorporating Mn(II) ions into the structures of vanadates the bandgap size can be decreased by an additional ∼0.5 to 1.0 eV, such as that used in the photocatalytic decomposition of methylene blue using visible light. Though these types of mixed-metal oxides have shown great potential in photocatalytic reactions, their structures have a relatively limited range of flexibility for tuning the connectivity and coordination environments of the transition metals responsible for their optical, electronic, and photocatalytic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Investigations into the use of visible-light energies to drive photocatalytic water-splitting reactions at the surfaces of metal-oxide semiconductors have drawn intense research interest in recent years, especially as a renewable route to produce hydrogen and oxygen using sunlight. Current approaches have focused on lowering the band gaps of metal oxides to absorb a greater fraction of sunlight while also maintaining a conduction band edge above the H2/H2O redox couple. Vanadium-containing oxides, such as V6O13, InVO4, BiVO4, and Ag3VO4, have been found with visible-light photocatalytic activities for O2 and H2 production. The 3d orbitals of vanadium act to lower the conduction band energies compared to the analogous titanate, niobate, and tantalate photocatalysts. Further, recent results indicate that by incorporating Mn(II) ions into the structures of vanadates the bandgap size can be decreased by an additional ~0.5 to 1.0 eV, such as that used in the photocatalytic decomposition of methylene blue using visible light. Though these types of mixed-metal oxides have shown great potential in photocatalytic reactions, their structures have a relatively limited range of flexibility for tuning the connectivity and coordination environments of the transition metals responsible for their optical, electronic, and photocatalytic properties.

elements.content: Organic/inorganic hybrids are a large and fast growing class of materials with structures that are determined by the specific combinations of organic ligands together with inorganic ions, and which can yield highly functionalized frameworks with potential applications in biomedicine, gas storage, energy storage, and photocatalysis. Metal-oxide/organic hybrids constitute one of the major subfields within this area that exhibit structures constructed from extended metal-oxide components (i.e., chains, layers, etc.) that are linked together by organic ligands. Thus, while their crystalline frameworks are built up from the extended [−O–M–O−] n connectivity, these may or may not also contain extended metal–organic components that are analogous to those in purely metal–organic frameworks. In recent years, a few metal–organic frameworks have been found to be active for water reduction to hydrogen under irradiation with the use of sacrificial reagents. Within hybrid oxide/organic structures, vanadate/organic hybrids have been of particular interest, owing to the multiple possible oxidation states (III, IV, and V) and coordination geometries of vanadate species that have yielded a large structural diversity. For example, these include [{Co(1,10-phenanthroline)2}2V6O17], [Ni(1,10-phenanthroline)2V4O11], [{Co2(4,4′-bipyridine)3 (H2O)2}V4O12]·2H2O, and [{Cu(pyrazole)4}2V10O28] that are constructed from one-dimensional to three-dimensional vanadate structures. However, relatively little has been previously explored on the optical and photocatalytic properties of these hybrid systems. Recent efforts in the Maggard group have focused on Mn(II)–organic/vanadate hybrids that could have the optimal band energies and visible-light bandgap sizes to drive water-splitting reactions. Examples in this system include [(Hen)2Mn(VO3)4], [C3N2H12][Mn(V4O12)(H2O)2], [Mn(1,10-phenanthroline)(H2O)V2O6], [enH2][Mn3(V2O7)2(H2O)2], and [H2pn][n2(C2O4)(V4O12)]. However, these hybrid compounds have not been previously investigated for their optical properties and photocatalytic activity.

In recent years, a few metal-organic frameworks have been found to be active for water reduction to hydrogen under irradiation with the use of sacrificial reagents. For example, these include [{Co(1,10-phenanthroline)2}2V6O17], [Ni(1,10-phenanthroline)2V4O11], [{Co2(4,4'-bipyridine)3 (H2O)2}V4O12]⋅2H2O, and [{Cu(pyrazole)4}2V10O28] that are constructed from one-dimensional to three-dimensional vanadate structures. Examples in this system include [(Hen)2Mn(VO3)4], [C3N2H12][Mn(V4O12)(H2O)2], [Mn(1,10-phenanthroline)(H2O)V2O6], [enH2][Mn3(V2O7)2(H2O)2], and [H2pn][n2(C2O4)(V4O12)]. elements.content: In addition to a greater degree of structural flexibility, hybrid compounds can undergo low-temperature structural transformations to new phases, and which have been investigated for their effects on physical properties such as magnetism, gas storage, catalysis, and thermal stability. Structural transformations of oxide/organic hybrids have typically been limited to the removal of small guest molecules (e.g., coordinated water molecules), such as in the layered hybrids [M2(pzc)2(H2O) x ][Mo5O16] and M(pzc)2(H2O)2AgReO4 (M = Co, Ni; pzc = pyrazinecarboxylate). However, examples of ligand-induced modifications of hybrid solids are still relatively few in number. For example, hybrid compounds in the copper–rhenate system could be structurally transformed with the removal or insertion of both bipyridine and water ligands. Thus, important physical properties expressed in a hybrid oxide/organic structure might potentially be carefully tuned using low-temperature structural modifications.

elements.content: Presented herein is the synthesis and characterization of a new layered hybrid Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I) and its low-temperature structural transformation to [Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy)] (II). The changes in crystalline structure, thermal stability, magnetic properties, optical bandgap sizes, and photocatalytic activities have been investigated. The [Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy)] hybrid is the first reported example of a metal-oxide/organic compound that shows visible-light photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production, as well as overall water splitting, from aqueous solutions. Electronic-structure calculations are used to probe the origins of these bandgap excitations and which illustrate the potential of these manganese–vanadate hybrids as a new class of photocatalysts.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All reagents were used as supplied by the manufacturer without further purification, including: Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O (98%, Alfa Aesar), NH4VO3 (99.99%, Aldrich), 2,2'-bipyridine (99%, Alfa Aesar), and glacial acetic acid (99.7%, Fisher). A reagent amount of deionized water was also used in each synthesis.

elements.content: Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I) was prepared via a hydrothermal procedure by heat-sealing all reactants into a polytetrafluoroethylene Teflon pouch (3″ × 3″), including 0.0175 g Mn(OAc)2·4H2O, 0.0169 g NH4VO3, 0.0390 g 2,2′-bipyridine, 0.0215 g glacial acetic acid, and ∼2 mL H2O in a molar ratio of 2:4:7:10:∼3000. The pouches were then placed into an ∼125 mL polytetrafluoroethylene-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was backfilled with ∼40 mL deionized water before closing. The reaction vessel was heated at 140 °C for six days in a convection oven and slowly cooled to room temperature at 6 °C/h. The products were washed with deionized water, collected, and dried at 60 °C overnight. Cubic-shaped orange-red crystals were obtained in a yield of ∼78% (based on vanadium). The synthesis of I was sensitive to both pH and reaction time. The absence of acetic acid or an insufficient reaction time (<6 days) leads to a mixture of I and Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II). The interconversion of these two compounds will be discussed in further detail later. The reaction temperature is also critical, as higher temperatures (160 and 180 °C) lead to the formation of Mn2V2O7. Unidentified brown powder or unreacted reagents were found when manganese nitrate, manganese chloride, or divanadium pentoxide were employed as reactants.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I) was prepared via a hydrothermal procedure by heat-sealing all reactants into a polytetrafluoroethylene Teflon pouch (3" × 3"), including 0.0175 g Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O, 0.0169 g NH4VO3, 0.0390 g 2,2'-bipyridine, 0.0215 g glacial acetic acid, and ~2 mL H2O in a molar ratio of 2:4:7:10:~3000. The pouches were then placed into an ~125 mL polytetrafluoroethylene-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was backfilled with ~40 mL deionized water before closing. The reaction vessel was heated at 140 °C for six days in a convection oven and slowly cooled to room temperature at 6 °C/h. The products were washed with deionized water, collected, and dried at 60 °C overnight. Cubic-shaped orange-red crystals were obtained in a yield of ~78% (based on vanadium). The synthesis of I was sensitive to both pH and reaction time. The absence of acetic acid or an insufficient reaction time (<6 days) leads to a mixture of I and Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II). The interconversion of these two compounds will be discussed in further detail later. The reaction temperature is also critical, as higher temperatures (160 and 180 °C) lead to the formation of Mn2V2O7. Unidentified brown powder or unreacted reagents were found when manganese nitrate, manganese chloride, or divanadium pentoxide were employed as reactants.

elements.content: Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II) was obtained by a hydrothermal procedure with a synthesis time that was shortened from 3 days to 10 h, compared to its literature report. The reactants were 0.0173 g Mn(OAc)2·4H2O, 0.0331 g NH4VO3, 0.0387 g 2,2′-bipyridine, 0.0213 g glacial acetic acid, and ∼2 mL H2O in a molar ratio of 2:8:7:10:∼3000 at 140 °C for 10 h. Needle-shaped brown crystals were obtained in a yield of ∼69% (based on vanadium). Each hybrid solid was obtained in a high phase purity (>95%), according to powder X-ray diffraction data shown in Figure S1 of the .

elements.content: A single-crystal data set for I was collected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. The initial unit cell determination and data reduction were performed using Bruker SAINT. The structure was solved by direct methods, and the structure refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods in SHELXS-97. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions that were fixed to ride on the parent carbon or oxygen atoms. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for I are given in Table . The refined atomic coordinates and isotropic equivalent displacement parameters of I are listed in Table S1 of the . Selected interatomic distances, angles, and bond valences can be found in Table S2 of the .

elements.content: UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-3600/3100 UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere. A pressed barium sulfate powder tablet was used as the reference. In accordance with the Kubelka–Monk theory of diffuse reflectance, the data were transformed using the function F(R ∞) = (1 – R ∞)2/(2R ∞). The data were plotted in the form of Tauc plots as [F(R) × hν] n vs hν (eV), where n = 2 for direct and n = 1/2 for indirect band gap transitions. The optical bandgap sizes were then estimated from the onset of absorption, as extrapolated from the linear rising section of the curve that intersects with the baseline. Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements were taking on a Quantum Design MPMS XL SQUID magnetometer under both zero-field cooled and field-cooled conditions. Magnetization measurements were recorded in the temperature range from 4–300 K at an applied field of 1 T after calibration and background subtraction.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Property Characterization

UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-3600/3100 UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere. A pressed barium sulfate powder tablet was used as the reference. In accordance with the Kubelka-Monk theory of diffuse reflectance, the data were transformed using the function F(R ∞) = (1 - R ∞)2/(2R ∞). The data were plotted in the form of Tauc plots as [F(R) × hν] n  vs hν (eV), where n = 2 for direct and n = 1/2 for indirect band gap transitions. The optical bandgap sizes were then estimated from the onset of absorption, as extrapolated from the linear rising section of the curve that intersects with the baseline. Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements were taking on a Quantum Design MPMS XL SQUID magnetometer under both zero-field cooled and field-cooled conditions. Magnetization measurements were recorded in the temperature range from 4-300 K at an applied field of 1 T after calibration and background subtraction.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were taken on a TA Instruments TGA Q50 by loading ∼0.0050g onto a platinum pan. The pan was equilibrated and tarred at room temperature and heated to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1 under a nitrogen flow. Specific surface areas were measured on a Quantachrome ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD. Samples were preheated to 140 °C under a nitrogen flow to degas for 3 h and then analyzed using a 30% He/N2 gas mixture and cooled with liquid nitrogen.

elements.content: The photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production was measured by suspending a weighed amount (∼20 mg) of the powdered samples (either pure or with a 1 wt % Pt surface cocatalyst) in an outer-irradiation quartz reaction cell which was filled with 45 mL of pure deionized water or a 20% aqueous methanol solution. During the photocatalysis reaction, the methanol is oxidized, while the water is reduced to hydrogen. Methanol serves as a hole scavenger, which is used to measure the H2 production rate alone. In order to remove any trapped gases on the particles’ surfaces, the solution was stirred in the dark for ∼0.5 h with continuous nitrogen purging. Next, the cell was then irradiated for reaction times of 5 to 8 h by a 1000 W high-pressure Xe arc lamp, which was equipped with an external fan, an IR water filter, and wavelength cutoff filters. The wavelength range of the light source was filtered to include either visible light only (λ > 420 nm) or both UV and visible light (λ > 200 nm). The photoreaction cell was connected to an L-shaped horizontal quartz tube to collect the evolved gases and to volumetrically measure the amount of gas produced. The collected gases were manually injected into a gas chromatograph (SRI MG #2; helium ionization and thermal conductivity detectors) to confirm the generated gases as H2 and O2.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalysis Testing

The photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production was measured by suspending a weighed amount (~20 mg) of the powdered samples (either pure or with a 1 wt % Pt surface cocatalyst) in an outer-irradiation quartz reaction cell which was filled with 45 mL of pure deionized water or a 20% aqueous methanol solution. During the photocatalysis reaction, the methanol is oxidized, while the water is reduced to hydrogen. Methanol serves as a hole scavenger, which is used to measure the H2 production rate alone. In order to remove any trapped gases on the particles' surfaces, the solution was stirred in the dark for ~0.5 h with continuous nitrogen purging. Next, the cell was then irradiated for reaction times of 5 to 8 h by a 1000 W high-pressure Xe arc lamp, which was equipped with an external fan, an IR water filter, and wavelength cutoff filters. The wavelength range of the light source was filtered to include either visible light only (λ > 420 nm) or both UV and visible light (λ > 200 nm). The photoreaction cell was connected to an L-shaped horizontal quartz tube to collect the evolved gases and to volumetrically measure the amount of gas produced. The collected gases were manually injected into a gas chromatograph (SRI MG #2; helium ionization and thermal conductivity detectors) to confirm the generated gases as H2 and O2.

elements.content: Electronic structure calculations were carried out using the package CASTEP, according to the plane-wave density functional theory. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof functional in the generalized gradient approximation, and ultrasoft core potentials were utilized in the calculations. Equally distributed k-points within the Brillouin zone were automatically calculated based on the Monkhorst–Pack scheme.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Structure Calculations

Electronic structure calculations were carried out using the package CASTEP, according to the plane-wave density functional theory. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional in the generalized gradient approximation, and ultrasoft core potentials were utilized in the calculations. Equally distributed k-points within the Brillouin zone were automatically calculated based on the Monkhorst-Pack scheme.

elements.content: Shown in Figure is an overall structural view of Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I) down the a axis with the unit cell outlined. The structure is comprised of manganese–vanadate layers that are coordinated by 2,2′-bipyridine ligands. Within these layers, the vanadium and manganese atoms are coordinated in tetrahedral and octahedral geometries, respectively. Shown in Figure , chains of vertex-bridged VO4 tetrahedra run along the b axis, and these in turn are bridged to two MnO3(bpy)(H2O) octahedra to form extended layers within the (110) plane. The local coordination environments are illustrated in Figure . Each VO4 tetrahedron is bridged via its apical oxygen atoms to two neighboring tetrahedra [O2 and O4, V–O at 1.620(6) – 1.812(6) Å]. Each MnO3(bpy)(H2O) octahedral environment consists of one water molecule [Mn–OH2 at 2.258(6) Å; a typical Mn–OH2 bond length is 2.21 Å], two nitrogen atoms from the 2,2′-bipyridine ligand [Mn–N at 2.247(7) – 2.251(7) Å], and three bridging oxygen atoms (O1, O3, and O5) to three different VO4 tetrahedra. Adjacent planes stack together at face-to-face distances between the bpy ligands of ∼3.4 Å and which is close to that typically observed for π–π interactions at ∼3.3 Å to ∼3.5 Å. The infrared spectrum of I is consistent with these structural features, as shown in Figure S2 of the . Intense sharp peaks are observed in the range of 1200–1600 cm–1 owing to the 2,2′-bipyridine ligand, and broad absorption bands in the 400 to 1000 cm–1 range are attributed to both V–O and Mn–O vibrations. The O–H groups from the coordinated water molecule are present as small broad peaks around 3300–3500 cm–1. These interatomic distances and structural features are consistent with related hybrid structures, such as α-Cu(bpy)V2O6, β-Cu(terpyridine)V2O6, and M(bpy)(H2O)V2O6 (M = Co and Ni).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

Shown in Figure  is an overall structural view of Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I) down the a axis with the unit cell outlined. The structure is comprised of manganese-vanadate layers that are coordinated by 2,2'-bipyridine ligands. Within these layers, the vanadium and manganese atoms are coordinated in tetrahedral and octahedral geometries, respectively. Shown in Figure , chains of vertex-bridged VO4 tetrahedra run along the b axis, and these in turn are bridged to two MnO3(bpy)(H2O) octahedra to form extended layers within the (110) plane. The local coordination environments are illustrated in Figure . Each VO4 tetrahedron is bridged via its apical oxygen atoms to two neighboring tetrahedra [O2 and O4, V-O at 1.620(6) - 1.812(6) Å]. Each MnO3(bpy)(H2O) octahedral environment consists of one water molecule [Mn-OH2 at 2.258(6) Å; a typical Mn-OH2 bond length is 2.21 Å], two nitrogen atoms from the 2,2'-bipyridine ligand [Mn-N at 2.247(7) - 2.251(7) Å], and three bridging oxygen atoms (O1, O3, and O5) to three different VO4 tetrahedra. Adjacent planes stack together at face-to-face distances between the bpy ligands of ~3.4 Å and which is close to that typically observed for π-π interactions at ~3.3 Å to ~3.5 Å. The infrared spectrum of I is consistent with these structural features, as shown in Figure S2 of the . Intense sharp peaks are observed in the range of 1200-1600 cm-1 owing to the 2,2'-bipyridine ligand, and broad absorption bands in the 400 to 1000 cm-1 range are attributed to both V-O and Mn-O vibrations. The O-H groups from the coordinated water molecule are present as small broad peaks around 3300-3500 cm-1. These interatomic distances and structural features are consistent with related hybrid structures, such as α-Cu(bpy)V2O6, β-Cu(terpyridine)V2O6, and M(bpy)(H2O)V2O6 (M = Co and Ni).

elements.content: Interestingly, the structure of I can be converted to Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II) through a hydrothermally mediated structural transformation. The hydrothermal reaction of I together with 2,2′-bipyridine and NH4VO3 in a mole ratio of 1:1:2 at 140 °C for 1 day results in single crystals of II. Alternatively, the hydrothermal reaction of II with the same molar amount of Mn(COOCH3)2·4H2O at 140 °C for 5 days results in single crystals of I. After each structural conversion, the phase purities of I and II were confirmed by PXRD, given in Figure S3 of the . Thus, the structural transformation between I and II can be driven reversibly using hydrothermal conditions. The synthesis and structure of II have been described previously, and its structure and local coordination environments are illustrated in Figure S4 of the . The magnetic susceptibility data of both I and II, given in Figures S5 and S6 of the , could be fitted to the Curie–Weiss model with the fitting parameters listed in Table . The data for both are consistent with Mn(II) (high spin; S = 5/2) and V(V) oxidation states. The small, negative values of θ indicate some short-range antiferromagnetic interactions between neighboring Mn(II) sites in each. The most significant difference is that the 2,2′-bipyridine ligands in I are coordinated only to the Mn cations, while in II the ligand is coordinated to both the Mn and V cations. This change in ligand coordination is driven by the reaction time as well as the compositional changes under the different reaction conditions.

The thermal stabilities, reversible water desorption, and decomposition route of compounds I and II were investigated by thermogravimetric and powder XRD analyses. The slow heating of compound I to 600 °C under flowing N2 shows three weight-loss steps, as shown in Figure S7 of the . The lowest-temperature weight loss corresponds to the loss of coordinated water molecules over a temperature range of 162 to 194 °C (exptl, 3.97%; calcd, 4.21%). The color of I changes from orange to dark red. However, the powder XRD shows a similar pattern as to that observed before the loss of all water (Figure S8 of the ), indicating the water can be relatively easy to remove with relatively small changes in the original crystalline structure. The expected composition would be approximately “Mn(bpy)V2O6”, with the removal of water potentially leaving open coordination sites on the Mn cations. This dehydrated product can be rehydrated in an aqueous solution at 60 °C for 12 h or at room temperature over a period of 72 h. After rehydration, the same powder XRD pattern is obtained as before the dehydration, shown in Figure S9 of the . The next two major weight loss steps starting at ∼291 °C and at ∼363 °C, correspond to the removal of the bipyridine ligand (total loss: exptl, 36.7%; calcd, 36.57%). The final dark-brown-colored residue was identified as MnV2O6 (Figure S10 of the ) with a few minor peaks identified as MnV2O6·H2O. By comparison, compound II does not contain coordinated water molecules and is stable up to ∼285 °C, with the loss of the bipyridine ligands (exptl, ∼40.36%; calcd, ∼41.8%) (Figure S11 of the ).

Water Absorption, Desorption, and Structural Decomposition

The slow heating of compound I to 600 °C under flowing N2 shows three weight-loss steps, as shown in Figure S7 of the . The lowest-temperature weight loss corresponds to the loss of coordinated water molecules over a temperature range of 162 to 194 °C (exptl, 3.97%; calcd, 4.21%). The color of I changes from orange to dark red. However, the powder XRD shows a similar pattern as to that observed before the loss of all water (Figure S8 of the ), indicating the water can be relatively easy to remove with relatively small changes in the original crystalline structure. The expected composition would be approximately "Mn(bpy)V2O6", with the removal of water potentially leaving open coordination sites on the Mn cations. This dehydrated product can be rehydrated in an aqueous solution at 60 °C for 12 h or at room temperature over a period of 72 h. After rehydration, the same powder XRD pattern is obtained as before the dehydration, shown in Figure S9 of the . The next two major weight loss steps starting at ~291 °C and at ~363 °C, correspond to the removal of the bipyridine ligand (total loss: exptl, 36.7%; calcd, 36.57%). The final dark-brown-colored residue was identified as MnV2O6 (Figure S10 of the ) with a few minor peaks identified as MnV2O6⋅H2O. By comparison, compound II does not contain coordinated water molecules and is stable up to ~285 °C, with the loss of the bipyridine ligands (exptl, ~40.36%; calcd, ~41.8%) (Figure S11 of the ).

elements.content: The optical bandgap sizes of Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I), Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II), and dehydrated “Mn(bpy)V2O6” (III) were measured with the use of Tauc plots obtained from UV–vis diffuse reflectance measurements, shown in Figure . The optical absorption edge of I is within the visible-light energy range, exhibiting a small indirect bandgap size of ∼2.2 eV. After dehydration of I, the indirect bandgap size is reduced to ∼1.65 eV for III, consistent with the change in color from orange to red. Similarly, compound II has an indirect bandgap size of ∼1.60 eV. In the case of “organic-free” MnV2O6·H2O, the bandgap size is ∼2.2 eV and is calculated to arise from an electronic excitation between the occupied Mn 3d/O 2p orbitals and the empty V 3d orbitals. In comparison to the simpler vanadates, such as lithium vanadate, the incorporation of Mn(II) into a vanadate structure yields a decrease in its bandgap size of ∼0.5 to 1.0 eV. This is consistent with the measured bandgap size for I. However, the incorporation of the coordinating organic ligand must be taken into consideration, as well as its effect on the coordination environments and structures of each of the hybrid compounds.

Optical Bandgap Sizes and Electronic Structures

The optical bandgap sizes of Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I), Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II), and dehydrated "Mn(bpy)V2O6" (III) were measured with the use of Tauc plots obtained from UV-vis diffuse reflectance measurements, shown in Figure . The optical absorption edge of I is within the visible-light energy range, exhibiting a small indirect bandgap size of ~2.2 eV. After dehydration of I, the indirect bandgap size is reduced to ~1.65 eV for III, consistent with the change in color from orange to red. Similarly, compound II has an indirect bandgap size of ~1.60 eV. In the case of "organic-free" MnV2O6⋅H2O, the bandgap size is ~2.2 eV and is calculated to arise from an electronic excitation between the occupied Mn 3d/O 2p orbitals and the empty V 3d orbitals. In comparison to the simpler vanadates, such as lithium vanadate, the incorporation of Mn(II) into a vanadate structure yields a decrease in its bandgap size of ~0.5 to 1.0 eV. This is consistent with the measured bandgap size for I. However, the incorporation of the coordinating organic ligand must be taken into consideration, as well as its effect on the coordination environments and structures of each of the hybrid compounds.

elements.content: Density-functional theory calculations (spin polarized) on the structures of I and II were performed in order to evaluate their band structures and the atomic contributions to the valence and conduction bands. Plots of the electron density originating from the edges of the conduction and valence band states, pink and blue shading, respectively, are shown in Figure overlaid on top of the crystalline structures of each. The calculated total and partial densities-of-states (DOS) for I and II are provided in Figure S12 of the , with the spin-down and spin-up components projected out to the left and right, respectively. For both I and II, the highest-occupied crystal orbitals primarily consist of the high-spin d5 orbital contributions from Mn(II), with some contributions from the N 2p orbitals on the bipyridine ligands. The lowest unoccupied crystal orbitals of I and II are found to consist of π* orbital contributions from the bipyridine ligands and that are, contrastingly, coordinated to Mn in I but to V in II. Shown in Figure is a closer view of the electron densities around the local coordination environments of Mn and V for I and II. The vanadium 3d-orbital contributions are found at only slightly higher energies in the conduction bands for both and must also contribute significantly to light absorption across the bandgap edges. This corresponds to a charge transfer between Mn(II)- and V(V)-based valence and conduction band states, respectively. Electronic structure calculations based on DFT are found to commonly underestimate the bandgap sizes of solids, but which exhibit accurate trends with respect to experimental data. The other spin component of both I and II exhibits a much larger energetic distance between the conduction and valence band states.

elements.content: The change in bpy-ligand coordination between I and II has a significant effect on their calculated electronic structures and bandgap sizes. The structure of I consists of VO4 tetrahedra that share vertices to form 1D chains, while in II the structure contains both VO4 tetrahedra and VO4(bpy) octahedra. The ligand π* orbitals are energetically more separated from the empty V d orbitals in II, and that lowers their energies in the conduction band compared to I. This change results in the smaller bandgap size of II compared to I. There is also an increased contribution from the vanadium 3d orbitals at energies lower in the conduction band. Mn(II) is in similar octahedral coordination geometries for both I and II, coordinated to one 2,2′-bipyridine ligand and four VO4 ligands in II or three VO4 and one H2O ligand in I. Thus, the relative energetic positions of the Mn d5 orbital contributions and the ligand contributions from O and N p orbitals are similar. The two Mn-based bands near the Fermi level arise from the d xz /d yz /d xy (lower energy) and d z2/d x2‑y2 (higher energy) contributions that follow a d orbital splitting pattern characteristic of an ideal octahedral geometry. The absence of extended Mn–O–Mn interactions results in less band broadening of the upper-energy valence band as compared to that arising from the extended V–O–V networks in each structure.

This change results in the smaller bandgap size of II compared to I. There is also an increased contribution from the vanadium 3d orbitals at energies lower in the conduction band. Thus, the relative energetic positions of the Mn d5 orbital contributions and the ligand contributions from O and N p orbitals are similar. The two Mn-based bands near the Fermi level arise from the d xz /d yz /d xy  (lower energy) and d z2/d x2-y2 (higher energy) contributions that follow a d orbital splitting pattern characteristic of an ideal octahedral geometry. The absence of extended Mn-O-Mn interactions results in less band broadening of the upper-energy valence band as compared to that arising from the extended V-O-V networks in each structure.

elements.content: The heterogeneous photocatalytic activities of both I and II were investigated by suspending a weighed amount of the powdered samples in aqueous solutions (with or without methanol as a hole scavenger and with or without Pt as a surface cocatalyst) and then irradiated under UV and/or visible-light irradiation. Compound I exhibited no detectable hydrogen production activity under both visible and UV light, even in the presence of methanol and with 1 wt % Pt surface cocatalyst. By contrast, II was found to exhibit photocatalytic activity for the production of hydrogen, as well as for total water splitting into both hydrogen and oxygen. Powder XRD was used to confirm that the crystalline structure was stable under these photocatalytic testing conditions, given in Figure S16 of the . Further experimental details (e.g., UV–vis, IR, and surface area measurements), regarding the potential dissolution and/or instability of II are provided in the . An approximate turnover number for the amount of hydrogen molecules produced per surface site was calculated based on the measured specific surface area (∼4.4 m2 g–1) and the average density of surface sites calculated for surface terminations of various planes of the crystal structure. Time course plots of the turnover numbers under different photocatalytic conditions are shown in Figure and in Figures S17 to S20 of the . Under visible-light irradiation, II exhibited a photocatalytic rate of ∼16 μmol H2 g–1 h–1 in 20% methanol solution and a similar rate of ∼21 μmol H2/1/2O2 g–1 h–1 in deionized water, as shown in Figure (panels a and c), with a turnover number of ∼8 to 9 after 6 h of testing. After coating with a 1 wt % Pt surface cocatalyst, II exhibited a significant activity for total water splitting, shown in Figure d, with a rate of ∼92 μmol H2/1/2O2 g–1 h–1 and an approximate turnover number after 7 h that reached >28 for H2. With methanol as the hole scavenger and a 1 wt % Pt surface cocatalyst, II exhibited a relatively lower activity for only hydrogen production of ∼65 μmol H2 g–1 h–1, shown in Figure b, with a turnover number of >12 after 4 h. Under ultraviolet light, neither 1 wt % Pt nor methanol were necessary, and the rate of hydrogen production was ∼71 μmol H2/1/2O2 g–1 h–1.

elements.content: Compound II represents the first known hybrid solid with photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production as well as for total water splitting under visible-light irradiation. Compared to I, the significant structural change in II is caused by the coordination of the 2,2′-bipyridine ligands to 1/4 of the vanadium sites. The calculated electronic structure shows that the ligand π* orbitals coordinated to the V(V) sites are at lower energies than the ligand π* orbitals coordinated to the Mn(II) sites. This can be seen in the electron density plots around the local coordination sites in Figure , where the lowest ligand π* orbitals are coordinated to Mn(II) in I but to V(V) in II. Thus, the absorption of visible light causes an electronic transition between the high-spin Mn(II) d5 orbitals and the ligand π* orbitals, or alternatively, to the empty V(V) d orbitals at slightly higher energies, followed by the relaxation of the electrons into the lower energy ligand π* orbitals. The latter electronic transition has a higher probability owing to the greater overlap of the crystal orbitals of the valence and conduction band states that are locally nearer to each other in the structure. As shown by the separation of the conduction and valence electron densities in Figure (left), compared to Figure (right), the structure of II facilitates the energetically downhill movement of the excited electrons away from the holes on the Mn(II) sites.

This can be seen in the electron density plots around the local coordination sites in Figure , where the lowest ligand π* orbitals are coordinated to Mn(II) in I but to V(V) in II. Thus, the absorption of visible light causes an electronic transition between the high-spin Mn(II) d5 orbitals and the ligand π* orbitals, or alternatively, to the empty V(V) d orbitals at slightly higher energies, followed by the relaxation of the electrons into the lower energy ligand π* orbitals. The latter electronic transition has a higher probability owing to the greater overlap of the crystal orbitals of the valence and conduction band states that are locally nearer to each other in the structure. As shown by the separation of the conduction and valence electron densities in Figure  (left), compared to Figure  (right), the structure of II facilitates the energetically downhill movement of the excited electrons away from the holes on the Mn(II) sites.

elements.content: A new manganese–vanadate hybrid structure, Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I), was synthesized by hydrothermal methods. Hybrid I can be easily reversibly converted to Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II) via low-temperature hydrothermal reaction conditions. Hybrid I exhibits the reversible absorption of lattice water molecules starting at ∼190 °C and which retains a roughly similar crystalline structure with the apparent composition Mn(bpy)V2O6. The optical band gaps were indirect with sizes of 2.20 eV for I and 1.60 eV for II. Electronic structure calculations show that the lowest-energy transitions between the valence and conduction band states are between the occupied Mn(II) (high spin d5 orbitals) and the empty bpy ligand π* orbitals and V(V) 3d orbitals. Compound II represents the first hybrid solid with photocatalytic activities for total water splitting, as well as for hydrogen production alone, in aqueous solutions under visible-light irradiation. By contrast, hybrid I showed no detectable photocatalytic activity. The high photocatalytic activity of II is attributed to a change in the ligand coordination that causes the excited electrons to migrate to lower-energy bpy ligand π* orbitals that are coordinated to V(V) rather than being coordinated to Mn(II) as in I. These results show the general utility of using new metal-oxide/organic structures in understanding the relationship of structure and photocatalytic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A new manganese-vanadate hybrid structure, Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I), was synthesized by hydrothermal methods. Hybrid I can be easily reversibly converted to Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II) via low-temperature hydrothermal reaction conditions. Hybrid I exhibits the reversible absorption of lattice water molecules starting at ~190 °C and which retains a roughly similar crystalline structure with the apparent composition Mn(bpy)V2O6. The optical band gaps were indirect with sizes of 2.20 eV for I and 1.60 eV for II. Electronic structure calculations show that the lowest-energy transitions between the valence and conduction band states are between the occupied Mn(II) (high spin d5 orbitals) and the empty bpy ligand π* orbitals and V(V) 3d orbitals. Compound II represents the first hybrid solid with photocatalytic activities for total water splitting, as well as for hydrogen production alone, in aqueous solutions under visible-light irradiation. By contrast, hybrid I showed no detectable photocatalytic activity. The high photocatalytic activity of II is attributed to a change in the ligand coordination that causes the excited electrons to migrate to lower-energy bpy ligand π* orbitals that are coordinated to V(V) rather than being coordinated to Mn(II) as in I. These results show the general utility of using new metal-oxide/organic structures in understanding the relationship of structure and photocatalytic properties.

cln_elements.content:
Mn(H2O)(bpy)V2O6 (I) was prepared via a hydrothermal procedure by heat-sealing all reactants into a polytetrafluoroethylene Teflon pouch (3″ × 3″), including 0.0175 g Mn(OAc)2·4H2O, 0.0169 g NH4VO3, 0.0390 g 2,2′-bipyridine, 0.0215 g glacial acetic acid, and ∼2 mL H2O in a molar ratio of 2:4:7:10:∼3000. The pouches were then placed into an ∼125 mL polytetrafluoroethylene-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was backfilled with ∼40 mL deionized water before closing. The reaction vessel was heated at 140 °C for six days in a convection oven and slowly cooled to room temperature at 6 °C/h. The products were washed with deionized water, collected, and dried at 60 °C overnight. Cubic-shaped orange-red crystals were obtained in a yield of ∼78% (based on vanadium). The synthesis of I was sensitive to both pH and reaction time. The absence of acetic acid or an insufficient reaction time (<6 days) leads to a mixture of I and Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II). The interconversion of these two compounds will be discussed in further detail later. The reaction temperature is also critical, as higher temperatures (160 and 180 °C) lead to the formation of Mn2V2O7. Unidentified brown powder or unreacted reagents were found when manganese nitrate, manganese chloride, or divanadium pentoxide were employed as reactants.

Mn(bpy)V4O11(bpy) (II) was obtained by a hydrothermal procedure with a synthesis time that was shortened from 3 days to 10 h, compared to its literature report. The reactants were 0.0173 g Mn(OAc)2·4H2O, 0.0331 g NH4VO3, 0.0387 g 2,2′-bipyridine, 0.0213 g glacial acetic acid, and ∼2 mL H2O in a molar ratio of 2:8:7:10:∼3000 at 140 °C for 10 h. Needle-shaped brown crystals were obtained in a yield of ∼69% (based on vanadium). Each hybrid solid was obtained in a high phase purity (>95%), according to powder X-ray diffraction data shown in Figure S1 of the .

cln_elements.content: The thermal stabilities, reversible water desorption, and decomposition route of compounds I and II were investigated by thermogravimetric and powder XRD analyses. The slow heating of compound I to 600 °C under flowing N2 shows three weight-loss steps, as shown in Figure S7 of the . The lowest-temperature weight loss corresponds to the loss of coordinated water molecules over a temperature range of 162 to 194 °C (exptl, 3.97%; calcd, 4.21%). The color of I changes from orange to dark red. However, the powder XRD shows a similar pattern as to that observed before the loss of all water (Figure S8 of the ), indicating the water can be relatively easy to remove with relatively small changes in the original crystalline structure. The expected composition would be approximately “Mn(bpy)V2O6”, with the removal of water potentially leaving open coordination sites on the Mn cations. This dehydrated product can be rehydrated in an aqueous solution at 60 °C for 12 h or at room temperature over a period of 72 h. After rehydration, the same powder XRD pattern is obtained as before the dehydration, shown in Figure S9 of the . The next two major weight loss steps starting at ∼291 °C and at ∼363 °C, correspond to the removal of the bipyridine ligand (total loss: exptl, 36.7%; calcd, 36.57%). The final dark-brown-colored residue was identified as MnV2O6 (Figure S10 of the ) with a few minor peaks identified as MnV2O6·H2O. By comparison, compound II does not contain coordinated water molecules and is stable up to ∼285 °C, with the loss of the bipyridine ligands (exptl, ∼40.36%; calcd, ∼41.8%) (Figure S11 of the ).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Water Absorption, Desorption, and Structural Decomposition

The thermal stabilities, reversible water desorption, and decomposition route of compounds I and II were investigated by thermogravimetric and powder XRD analyses. The slow heating of compound I to 600 °C under flowing N2 shows three weight-loss steps, as shown in Figure S7 of the . The lowest-temperature weight loss corresponds to the loss of coordinated water molecules over a temperature range of 162 to 194 °C (exptl, 3.97%; calcd, 4.21%). The color of I changes from orange to dark red. However, the powder XRD shows a similar pattern as to that observed before the loss of all water (Figure S8 of the ), indicating the water can be relatively easy to remove with relatively small changes in the original crystalline structure. The expected composition would be approximately "Mn(bpy)V2O6", with the removal of water potentially leaving open coordination sites on the Mn cations. This dehydrated product can be rehydrated in an aqueous solution at 60 °C for 12 h or at room temperature over a period of 72 h. After rehydration, the same powder XRD pattern is obtained as before the dehydration, shown in Figure S9 of the . The next two major weight loss steps starting at ~291 °C and at ~363 °C, correspond to the removal of the bipyridine ligand (total loss: exptl, 36.7%; calcd, 36.57%). The final dark-brown-colored residue was identified as MnV2O6 (Figure S10 of the ) with a few minor peaks identified as MnV2O6⋅H2O. By comparison, compound II does not contain coordinated water molecules and is stable up to ~285 °C, with the loss of the bipyridine ligands (exptl, ~40.36%; calcd, ~41.8%) (Figure S11 of the ).
